Problem:
Consider a control system where the output \( y(t) \) is governed by the linear time-invariant differential equation \( \dot{y} = My + Nu \), with \( M \) and \( N \) as constant matrices and \( u(t) \) as the control input. An operator \( T(y) = e^{Ky} \) is introduced, where \( K \) is a constant matrix.

If \( T(y) \) is applied to the initial condition \( y_0 \) at t = 0, and \( y(t) \) is then allowed to evolve under \( \dot{y} = My \) without further intervention, will \( y(t) \) at t = T be the same as if \( y_0 \) was directly evolved under \( \dot{y} = My \) without applying \( T(y) \)?
Explanation: Applying \( T(y) \) to \( y_0 \) fundamentally changes the initial condition by the transformation \( e^{Ky_0} \), which affects the entire evolution of the system under \( \dot{y} = My \). The system’s trajectory, therefore, changes, resulting in a different state at time T.
